The view was expressed that this ^section of opinion, which had made itself strongly felt, would not.be fully satisfied by anything short of the establishment of a separateMinistry of Town and Country Planning.On the other hand, objection was felt to the creation of a new ministry at this juncture.The general view of the War Cabinet was that the existingfunctions in regard to town and country planning should be trans-ferred to the Minister of Works and Buildings, whose title shouldbe altered to " Minister of Works and Planning."It was also urged that it was hardly necessary, and perhapsmisleading, to describe the proposed body of Ministers as a" National Development Executive," and that the establishment atthis juncture of a body of this kind, which comprised a number ofMinisters who were fully employed on duties concerned with thewar, was open to criticism.The War Cabinet's conclusions were as follows : (1) The existing statutory duties in regard to town and country planning, exercised by the Minister of Health inEngland and Wales, should be transferred to theMinister of Works and Buildings, whose title should be changed to "Minister of Works and Planning." TheMinister's planning functions should be on the lines proposed in paragraph 6 (vii) of W.P. (42) 20.(2) The Minister of Works and Planning should be assisted bya Committee of Officials representing the Departmentsconcerned. The main functions of this Committee wouldbe to ensure that, so far as possible, the national policyof urban and rural development was carried out as asingle and consistent whole.(3) This body should have access to a Cabinet Committee of theMinisters in charge of the Departments concerned (seeparagraph 6 (iv) of W.P. (42) 20) under the Chairman-ship of the Minister without Portfolio. The functionsof this Cabinet Committee would be to settle matters inregard to town and country planning which could not bedetermined at the official level and on which referenceto the War Cabinet was unnecessary.(4) This Cabinet Committee would supersede the Council ofMinisters sitting under the Chairmanship of theMinister of Works and Buildings, to co-ordinate thework of forward planning with the current administra-tion of existing powers. , 4(5) The Secretary of State for Scotland would be responsiblefor the exercise in Scotland of the functions in regard totown and country planning to be exercised in Englandand Wales by the Minister of Works and Planning.(6) A public announcement should be made on the above lines inreply to Lord Samuel's Motion on the followingWednesday.
